PSL101.name: Frontiers in Physiology
PSL101.description: Introduction to the field of physiology and recent trends in physiological research, including an overview of biomedical careers. Campus and Internet resources to achieve academic success and career goals.
PSL101.restrictions: Open to freshmen or sophomores in the College of Natural Science or in the Lyman Briggs College.

PSL250.name: Introductory Physiology
PSL250.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL250.description: Function, regulation and integration of organs and organ systems of higher animals emphasizing human physiology.
PSL250.restrictions: Not open to students in the Physiology major.

PSL310.name: Physiology for Pre-Health Professionals
PSL310.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL310.description: Human organ system physiology with clinical applications for students entering health care fields.
PSL310.prerequisite: BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145 or ANTR 350

PSL311L.name: Physiology Laboratory for Pre-Health Professionals
PSL311L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSL311L.description: Laboratory exercises in human and animal physiology, including neural, sensory, muscle, cardiovascular, and urinary function, with an emphasis on the integration of physiological systems. Laboratory exercises relevant for pre-health students and the development of data analysis and problem solving skills.
PSL311L.prerequisite: (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172) and ((PSL 310 or concurrently) or (PSL 432 or concurrently))

PSL331.name: Concepts and Critical Thinking in Physiology
PSL331.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSL331.description: Knowledge, skills, and approaches necessary to create deep understanding of biological concepts for success in advanced physiology courses
PSL331.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors in the Physiology Major or in the Lyman Briggs Physiology Coordinate Major. Approval of department.

PSL425.name: Physiological Biophysics
PSL425.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSL425.description: The quantitative physical phenomena underlying kinetics and equilibria of physiological processes.
PSL425.prerequisite: PSL 250 or PSL 310 or (PSL 431 and PSL 432)

PSL431.name: Human Physiology I
PSL431.description: Molecular basis of physiological control systems, physiology of excitable cells, autonomic nervous system, function and regulation of cardiovascular and respiratory systems.
PSL431.prerequisite: (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172)

PSL432.name: Human Physiology II
PSL432.description: Continuation of PSL 431. Function and regulation of the digestive, endocrine, renal, and reproductive systems. Integration of physiological responses.
PSL432.prerequisite: (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172) and PSL 431

PSL450.name: Physiology in Health and Disease
PSL450.description: Advanced topics in normal and abnormal physiology. Chronic diseases, disease progression, and animal models of disease.
PSL450.prerequisite: (PSL 431 and PSL 432) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
PSL450.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Lyman Briggs Physiology Coordinate Major or in the Physiology major.

PSL460.name: Topics in Physiology (W)
PSL460.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL460.description: In-depth exploration of contemporary areas of physiology and human disease, emphasizing scientific literacy and effective written and oral communication.
PSL460.prerequisite: (PSL 431 and (PSL 432 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
PSL460.restrictions: Open to seniors or juniors in the Physiology Major or in the Lyman Briggs Physiology Coordinate Major.
PSL460.alias: PSL 421, PSL 438, PSL 439, PSL 440, PSL 441, PSL 442, PSL 443, PSL 444, PSL 445, PSL 446, PSL 447, PSL 448, PSL 449

PSL475L.name: Capstone Laboratory in Physiology
PSL475L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL475L.description: Laboratory exercises in human and animal physiology, including cardiovascular, respiratory, neural, muscle, sensory, and hormonal function, as well as systems physiology studies in exercise and systemic reflexes.
PSL475L.prerequisite: (PSL 431) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
PSL475L.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Physiology Major or in the Lyman Briggs Physiology Coordinate Major.

PSL480.name: Special Problems in Physiology
PSL480.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL480.description: Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member.
PSL480.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Physiology Major. Approval of department.

PSL490.name: Independent Research in Physiology
PSL490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL490.description: Supervised laboratory research in physiology under the direction of a faculty member.
PSL490.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Physiology Major. Approval of department.

PSL499.name: Physiology Senior Research Thesis
PSL499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL499.description: Independent research with faculty supervision culminating in a thesis.
PSL499.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Physiology Major or in the Lyman Briggs Physiology Coordinate Major. Approval of department; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 12 credits combined between PSL 480 and PSL 490 and PSL 499.

PSL534.name: Cell Biology and Physiology I
PSL534.description: Modern concepts of cell biology as a basis for understanding the physiology of human tissues and organ systems in health and disease.
PSL534.restrictions: Open only to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine or College of Osteopathic Medicine.

PSL535.name: Cell Biology and Physiology II
PSL535.description: Modern concepts of cell biology as a basis for understanding the physiology of human tissues and organ systems in health and disease. Continuation of PSL 534.
PSL535.restrictions: Open only to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine or the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

PSL539.name: Principles of Cell Biology and Pathophysiology
PSL539.description: Modern concepts of human cell biology as a basis for understanding integration of structure (histology) and function (physiology) in health and disease (pathology). Introduction to adaptive growth response, cell injury, inflammation, hemodynamic disorders, and tissue repair.
PSL539.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

PSL552.name: Medical Neuroscience
PSL552.description: Correlation of normal structure and function of the human nervous system with clinical testing, classical lesions, and common diseases.
PSL552.restrictions: Open only to graduate-professional students in the Colleges of Human Medicine and Osteopathic Medicine.

PSL611.name: Research Problems in Physiology Clerkship
PSL611.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL611.description: Individual work on a research problem.

PSL803.name: Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Neuroscience II
PSL803.description: Electrical and intra- and extracellular signaling mechanisms of neurons and glia in health and disease in the developing and mature nervous system.
PSL803.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Program in Neuroscience. Approval of department.

PSL813.name: Molecular Mechanism of Human Disease and Targeted Therapies
PSL813.description: Mechanisms and pathways underlying human disease and therapeutic strategies.

PSL825.name: Cell Structure and Function
PSL825.description: Molecular basis of structure and function. Cell properties

PSL827.name: Physiology and Pharmacology of Excitable Cells
PSL827.description: Function of neurons and muscle at the cellular level
PSL827.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Natural Science or in the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology or approval of department.

PSL828.name: Cellular and Integrative Physiology I
PSL828.description: Cellular physiology as basis for understanding integrative functions of various body systems, including nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, urinary, muscle and kidney.

PSL829.name: Cellular and Integrative Physiology II
PSL829.description: Cellular physiology as basis for understanding functions of various body systems including blood, blood cells, endocrine, reproductive and gastrointestinal.

PSL839.name: Systems Neuroscience
PSL839.description: Anatomy, pharmacology, and physiology of multicellular neural systems. Sensory, motor, autonomic, and chemo-regulatory systems in vertebrate brains.
PSL839.restrictions: Open to graduate students or human medicine students or osteopathic medicine students in the College of Natural Science or in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Human Medicine or in the College of Osteopathic Medicine or in the College of Social Science or in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

PSL899.name: Master's Thesis Research
PSL899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL899.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Physiology major.

PSL950.name: Topics in Physiology
PSL950.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL950.description: Classical and modern concepts in selected areas of physiology.

PSL980.name: Problems in Physiology
PSL980.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

PSL999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
PSL999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSL999.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Physiology major.
